questions.text: Criminal responsibility of Insane is defined in: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McNaughten's Rule

 

“McNaughten’s Rule” also known as “Legal test of insanity”, “right or wrong test” is the legal standard for determining criminal responsibility in cases of insanity.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Curren's rule: of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.

 

Option C. Durham 's rule: of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Option D. American law institute test: (1972) A person is not responsible for the crime, if at the time of committing it, he lacks adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust it to the requirements of the law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule is defined by section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)

 

It states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

 

It implies that the defendant was unable to distinguish between right and wrong or otherwise didn't understand what they did because of a "disease of the mind."

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

 

The correct matching of the items is as follows:

 

  • Eonism (Transvestism): Wearing clothes of the opposite sex, often for sexual gratification or due to gender identity disorder.
  • Frotteurism: The act of rubbing one's genitals against another person, usually in a crowded place.
  • Necrophilia: Engaging in sexual activity with dead bodies.
  • Exhibitionism: The act of exposing one's genitalia to unsuspecting individuals.
  • Passive Algoglenia: Deriving sexual gratification from experiencing pain, also known as masochism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism (Transvestism) is wearing clothes of the opposite sex, Frotteurism is rubbing genitals against another person, Necrophilia is having sex with dead bodies, Exhibitionism is exposing genitalia to unsuspecting individuals, and Passive Algoglenia is gratification from experiencing pain.

choices.text: Examination by Male doctor with female attendant
Vaginal swab examination is not necessary
Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynecologist

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was raped by her neighbor. She presents to the hospital with 25 weeks of pregnancy. What should not be done? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynecologist

 

According to the MTP Act, the termination of pregnancy due to rape is allowed only upto 24 weeks. Also, since this girl is a minor (< 18 years) the consent of the guardian is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Examination by Male doctor with female attendant: Male doctor can always examine a female patient, if a female attendant is present

 

Option B) Vaginal swab examination is not necessary: Evidence of rape remains only till 96 hours. Here pregnancy is 25 weeks, so vaginal swab will not help to detect semen

 

Option C) Confirm pregnancy by USG: After 21 weeks the pregnancy can be confirmed by simple palpation of fetal parts. USG may be done for other reasons, but not to confirm pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP ACT (Latest amendment 2021)

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and abdominal pain. He reports memory loss and reveals that he works at a battery recycling plant. On examination, a noticeable foot drop in both lower extremities is seen. Laboratory testing shows elevated blood lead levels. Which enzyme is affected in the given scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase

 

The question clearly indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning (elevated blood levels and associated clinical features)

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis through inhibition of multiple enzymes involved in heme synthesis pathway, of which main inhibited enzymes are:

 

  • ALAD (Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase)- Mnemonic ALAD sounds like lead
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
  • Ferrochelatase

 

This leads to increased levels of multiple precursors of Heme production like:

 

  • Protoporphyrin
  • Coproporphyrin
  • δ-amino levulinic acid

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen III: Not directly inhibited by lead. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is involved in the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III.

 

Option C. Uroporphyrinogen I: Not directly involved in lead poisoning. Uroporphyrinogen I is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway but not specifically inhibited by lead.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Not involved in the heme synthesis pathway. This enzyme is part of the metabolic pathway converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective

 

Lead poisoning primarily inhibits the enzyme Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase (ALAD), leading to disruptions in the heme synthesis pathway and accumulation of heme precursors.

choices.text: Legs, abdomen, face, neck, eyelids
Myocardium, eyelids, neck and lower jaw, face, chest
Upper extremities, chest, face, eyelids, neck and jaw
Fingers and toes, legs, upper extremities, abdomen, chest

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is found dead in his home, and the forensic team is called to assess the time of death. Upon examination, the man exhibits stiffness in his eyelids and lower jaw, but his chest and arms remain flexible. Based on Nysten’s rule, rigor mortis develops sequentially from the head downward through specific muscle groups. In what order does rigor mortis typically develop, starting from the earliest affected muscles to the latest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Myocardium, eyelids, neck and lower jaw, face, chest

 

Explanation:

 

Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups, beginning from the head and progressing down the body. According to this rule, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium, followed by the eyelids, neck, and lower jaw. It then progresses to the face, chest, upper extremities, abdomen, legs, and finally the fingers and toes. This systematic progression helps forensic experts estimate the time of death by observing which muscle groups have stiffened, reflecting rigor mortis development from top to bottom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nysten’s rule outlines the predictable sequence of rigor mortis onset, starting with the smallest muscles and progressing downward: myocardium, eyelids, neck and jaw, face, chest, upper extremities, abdomen, legs, and finally fingers and toes. Recognizing this pattern is essential in forensic pathology to help determine the approximate time of death based on the extent of muscle stiffness observed.

choices.text: Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition.
In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.
Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source.
Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about postmortem changes? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts. In drowning, the body floats with face down, buttocks up, legs and arms hanging down in front of the body as shown below:

 

 

Hence, in drowning the postmortem staining occurs over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition: Greenish discoloration after death occurs due to sulfmethemoglobin.

 

Earliest external sign of decomposition: greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

 

Earliest internal sign of putrefaction: reddish brown discoloration of aorta followed by greenish discoloration of undersurface of liver.

 

Option C. Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source: Adipocere formation requires presence of moisture, hence found in bodies recovered from water.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles: Cadaveric spasm is the localized sustained contraction of a specific set of muscles which were used profusely just before death. There is no primary relaxation phase and these muscles become stiff and rigid immediately after death. For example, in case of death due to drowning, if the person grabs hold of grass, then immediately after death, he would be having a clenched fist with some grass in it. On the contrary rigor mortis occurs in all the body muscles gradually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts of the body based on the position at the time of death. In drowning cases, it affects the face, neck, chest, and limbs, not just the lower limbs.

questions.text: Identify the person to whom the First-hand knowledge rule is applicable? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common witness

 

The first-hand knowledge rule applies to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts directly observed by them. This rule ensures that the testimony provided is based on direct observation and personal experience rather than hearsay or second-hand information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Handwriting expert: An expert witness who provides testimony based on specialized knowledge or expertise, rather than direct personal observation of the facts in question.

 

Option C. Doctor: A medical professional who may provide expert testimony based on their medical expertise, rather than direct observation of the facts in question.

 

Option D. A hostile witness is a witness who appears to be refusing to fully testify in support of the person who called them or testifies in a way that significantly differs from their pre-trial.

 

Note : An expert witness is a person with extensive experience or knowledge in a specific field or discipline beyond that expected from a layperson. The expert witness's duty is to apply their expertise to give a professional opinion to the tribunal or court on particular matters in dispute. Doctors, handwriting/ fingerprints/ firearms experts come under this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-hand knowledge rule ensures that the testimony provided by a common witness is based on direct observation and personal experience, thereby maintaining the integrity and reliability of the evidence presented in court.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

choices.text: Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV
ASV is the mainstay of treatment
Current ASV in India is less effective against humped pit viper

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the management of snakebite in India? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite 

 

Neostigmine (along with atropine) can be used for neurotoxic snakes (both cobra and krait). But the usefulness is much less in krait bite, and much more in cobra bite.

 

  • Mechanism of Neostigmine: Neostigmine is the inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase enzyme. So, it will act as an antidote to acetylcholinesterase enzyme component of cobra and krait venom
  • Why Neostigmine is less useful in Krait: Krait, in addition also have some toxins that inhibit the release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal at neuromuscular junction. Neostigmine will not be helpful to counter the effect of these toxins. 
  • Why Atropine used with Neostigmine: As neostigmine increases the amount of acetylcholine, both nicotinic and muscarinic effects occur. But to treat snake bite we need only nicotinic effects at neuromuscular junction. Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent and helps to counter the muscarinic effects of nicotine, especially bradycardia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV:
This statement is true. Neostigmine can be part of the management for neurotoxic snake envenomations, and ventilatory support may be necessary if there is significant respiratory compromise. ASV (Anti-Snake Venom) is also used as it neutralizes the venom.

 

Option C. ASV is the mainstay of treatment: True. ASV remains the primary treatment for snakebite envenomations in India, effectively neutralizing the venom of various snake species.

 

Option D. Current ASV in India is less effective against humped pit viper: This is true. There are regional variations in the efficacy of ASV based on the specific snake species prevalent in those regions, and ASV formulations may be less effective against certain species, such as the humped pit viper.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of snake bite:

 

  • First Aid treatment have limited role. Reassure the patient, immobilize the limb and keep it below the heart level. Light pressure can be applied in neurotoxic snakes.
  • Anti-snake venom (ASV) is the main treatment for snake bite. It contains antivenom against the 4 common poisonous snakes in India (Cobra, Krait, Russel’s viper and saw scaled viper). It does not contain antivenom against humped pit viper, which is found in some states of India, but still can be partially effective in it due to cross antibodies formation. 
  • Treatment in addition to ASV:
    • Vasculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis and Blood Transfusion
    • Musculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis
    • Neurotoxic snakes: Ventilation and Neostigmine (along with atropine)

 

Other Options: Explained above

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.text: Frotteurism is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person

 

Frotteurism involves the act of touching or rubbing one's genitals against another non-consenting individual in a sexual manner, to attain sexual gratification.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Eonism (also known as Transvestism)
  • Description: Involves obtaining sexual pleasure or emotional satisfaction by wearing clothes traditionally associated with the opposite sex.

 

Option B. Desire to seek surgery to become a member of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Transsexualism
  • Description: Involves a strong desire to undergo surgery to change one's biological sex to align with one's gender identity.

 

Option D. Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

 

  • Term: Exhibitionism
  • Description: Involves exposing one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger for sexual gratification. This behavior is typically intended to shock or arouse the observer.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Act of rubbing one's genitals against another person without their consent to achieve sexual arousal or gratification - Frotteurism
  • Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex – Eonism
  • Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex - Transsexualism
  • Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger- Exhibitionism

questions.text: Identify the plant given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Argemone Mexicana

 

  • The plant in the image is Argemone Mexicana.
  • It is also called as Mexican prickly poppy.
  • Oil extract can cause Epidemic dropsy characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca.
  • Identification: Yellow flowers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura alba: Datura alba, also known as white datura, has large trumpet-shaped white flowers and is a different plant with its own toxic properties, primarily affecting the nervous system.

 

 

Option C. Abrus precatorius: Abrus precatorius, commonly known as Rosary pea or jequirity, has distinctive red seeds with a black spot. The plant is different from Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Option D. Erthyroxylum coca: Erthyroxylum coca is the plant from which cocaine is derived. It has small white flowers and red berries, and does not resemble Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plant Argemone mexicana, identifiable by its yellow flowers and spiny leaves, is known for its toxic oil extract which can cause Epidemic dropsy.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture sustained in a motorcycle accident? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hinge fracture

 

Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Pond fracture is the other name of pediatric depressed skull fracture. It is primarily due to increased plasticity of the immature skeleton in young children. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hinge’ (also called Motorcyclist):

 

  • linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves,
  • Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents).
  • Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

choices.text: Clean cut incised wound

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he was attacked by his lover’s husband with an axe. On examination, crushing of the hair bull was seen. Identify the type of wound? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lacerated wound  

 

  • The type of wound in which the crushing of the hair bulb is seen is a lacerated wound.
  • Laceration- A laceration is a wound that is produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged
  • It is produced by blunt weapons or heavy relatively sharp-edged weapons such as axe.
  • In scalp lacerations hair bulbs, nerves, and vessels, are irregularly torn and crushed

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Clean cut incised wound: Typically has clean, sharp edges caused by sharp instruments like knives or razors.
  • Option C. Chop wound: While an axe can cause a chop wound, the presence of crushed hair bulbs suggests more of a laceration pattern.
  • Option D. Avulsion injury: Involves the skin and underlying tissues being forcibly detached from the body.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.
  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.
  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.
  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact
  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

choices.text: Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

questions.text: What is the cause of the condition given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

 

The above image shows washerwoman's feet/ washerwoman's skin. It is seen in a case of immersion in water (both antemortem as well as postmortem drowning). It denotes skin maceration or swelling and wrinkling of the skin due to water absorption. Following changes are seen in washerwoman skin:

 

  • Wrinkling: After 3 hrs of immersion
  • Soddening (filled with water): After 12 hrs of immersion
  • Bleaching (whitening): After 36 hrs of immersion
  • Peeling: after 72 hrs of immersion

 

In the image, bleaching can be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy typically presents with sensory deficits, pain, or ulcers but does not cause the skin changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Hanging: Hanging does not cause the specific wrinkling and bleaching of the skin seen in the image.

 

Option D. Burns of foot: Burns would result in charring, blistering, and other thermal injuries, not the wrinkling and bleaching seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's feet (or skin) is characterized by swelling, wrinkling, and bleaching due to prolonged immersion in water, typically observed after more than 36 hours.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is found deceased at his home, and a forensic examination is conducted to determine the time of death. On inspection, the body shows prominent greenish-black streaks visible along the blood vessels on the skin, primarily over the lower extremities, resembling a branching pattern. The skin has a discolored appearance ranging from green to black. Based on these findings, which postmortem condition is most likely represented in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Marbling

 

Explanation:

 

Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by the visible appearance of blood vessels on the skin as greenish-black streaks. This condition occurs due to the breakdown of hemoglobin in the blood, leading to the formation of sulfmethemoglobin, which causes the characteristic discoloration of the skin. Marbling typically starts around 24 hours after death and becomes more prominent within 36-48 hours. The process is part of the early stages of decomposition, where the visible blood vessels create a marbled appearance due to bacterial gas production and the breakdown of hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Livor mortis: Livor mortis, also known as postmortem hypostasis, refers to the pooling of blood in dependent parts of the body, leading to purplish-red discoloration of the skin. It does not cause the greenish-black streaks along blood vessels seen in marbling.

 

C. Tardieu spots: Tardieu spots are petechial hemorrhages seen on the skin, conjunctivae, and other mucosal surfaces, often associated with asphyxial deaths. They do not present with the distinct marbling pattern seen on the skin in decomposition.

 

D. Putrefaction: Putrefaction refers to the process of decay and decomposition of the body, characterized by bloating, gas formation, and the release of foul odors. While marbling is an early stage of putrefaction, the term putrefaction alone does not specifically describe the marbling pattern of the blood vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling is an early postmortem change characterized by greenish-black discoloration of the skin along blood vessels due to the formation of sulfmethemoglobin during decomposition. This change typically begins around 24 hours after death and becomes prominent within 36-48 hours, serving as an important indicator of the time frame in postmortem examinations.

Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue
