questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic comes to the casualty after being hurt in a fight with a stranger. A lacerated wound is seen over his skull. Which of the following is the correct mechanism of this lacerated wound? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

 

The laceration shown above is an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shearing force: Shearing force typically causes a different type of laceration, not the incised-like laceration seen in the image.

 

Option B. Impact of a semi sharp-edged object: This might cause a different wound pattern, more akin to a cut or a clean incision rather than a laceration.

 

Option C. Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue: This causes stretch lacerations, which do not match the appearance of the wound shown.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.

  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.

  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.

  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact

  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.

  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

questions.text:
An abandoned deceased male fetus was discovered and brought for autopsy. The following findings were noted: (AIIMS NOV 2016)

 

  • Crown-to-rump length (CRL): 23 cm
  • Total length (head to feet): 63 cm
  • Eyes open
  • Pupillary membrane absent
  • Testes located at the superficial inguinal ring
  • Fetal weight: 1000 gm

 

Based on these observations, what is the estimated age of the fetus? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 7 months

 

Explanation:

 

Several key findings point towards a fetal age of 7 months:

 

  1. Pupillary membrane: The absence of the pupillary membrane indicates a fetal age of at least 7 months, as this structure typically disappears around this time.
  2. Testes location: The descent of the testes to the superficial inguinal ring is also consistent with a 7-month-old fetus.
  3. Fetal weight: The fetal weight of 1000 gm falls within the expected range for a 7-month-old fetus (900-1200 gm).

 

Additionally, we can estimate the age using Hasse's rule, which states:

 

  • For the first 5 months: Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (CHL) in cm.
  • After 5 months: Age in months = CHL in cm / 5
  • We know CRL = 2/3 CHL, so CHL = 3/2 CRL = (3/2) * 23 cm = 34.5 cm
  • Since the fetus is older than 5 months, we use the second part of Hasse's rule: Age in months = 34.5 cm / 5 = 7 months (approximately)

 

This further supports the estimated fetal age of 7 months.

 

Other Options:

  • a. 5 months: At 5 months, the pupillary membrane is still present, and the testes are usually located higher in the abdomen.
  • b. 6 months: Similar to 5 months, the pupillary membrane is still present at 6 months, and the testes have not yet descended to the superficial inguinal ring.
  • d. 8 months: At 8 months, the testes would likely be palpable in the scrotum, and the fetal weight would be higher (1.5-2 kg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of the pupillary membrane, the descent of the testes to the superficial inguinal ring, and a fetal weight of around 1000 gm are key indicators of a 7-month-old fetus. Hasse's rule can provide an additional estimate of fetal age based on crown-heel length.

questions.text: A young woman was found dead at home under mysterious circumstances. Her live-in partner was reported missing. These were the postmortem images taken by the forensic photographer. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling  

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck

 

In throttling, the following mechanisms may lead to death:

 

Autopsy findings:

 

  • Bruising on the neck

  • Abrasions of the neck

  • Contused tissues of the neck

 

Cause of death in throttling:

 

  • Occlusion of blood supply to the blood to the brain - carotid arteries

  • Occlusion of the airway leading to asphyxia

  • Carotid sinus pressure causing cardiac arrest

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strangulation: While strangulation is a general term that includes throttling, the specific mechanism in this case is manual strangulation, which is best described as throttling.

 

Option C. Hanging: Hanging typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck and different positional signs, which are not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Mugging: Mugging involves external pressure applied using limbs or objects, which generally do not produce the distinct bruising and abrasions seen in throttling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing bruises, abrasions, and contusions, and can lead to death by occlusion of blood supply or airway and pressure on the carotid sinus.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime.

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police not under rank of sub inspector: Involved in criminal investigations but does not bear the onus of proof in civil negligence cases.

 

Option C. Magistrate: Presides over legal proceedings but does not bear the onus of proof.

 

Option D. Doctor: The doctor is the defendant in a negligence case and does not bear the initial burden of proof.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

 

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

choices.text: Suicidal firearm wounds
Traumatic asphyxia
Drowning
Electrocution

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in all except: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Traumatic asphyxia

 

Option B. Traumatic Asphyxia : This condition typically results from a severe crush injury to the chest or abdomen that prevents normal respiration. Cadaveric spasms are less likely because the death does not involve a sudden catastrophic nervous system event that would induce immediate muscle contraction.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Suicidal Firearm Wounds : Cadaveric spasm may occur in cases of suicidal firearm wounds due to the intense muscle contraction at the moment of death. The individual might be holding a weapon tightly, which can lead to a cadaveric spasm preserving the grip on the firearm.

 

Option C. Drowning : Cadaveric spasm can occur during drowning as the individual may be holding onto objects or vegetation in a panic, and these grips can become fixed due to the sudden cessation of brain function.

 

Option D. Electrocution : Electrocution can cause instantaneous and intense muscular contractions and possibly a cadaveric spasm. This can result in the deceased gripping onto any objects they were touching at the time of electrocution.

 

Educational objective :

 

Cadaveric spasm is a rare phenomenon usually associated with the sudden and intense activation of muscles at the time of death. It is most commonly seen in deaths involving intense emotional or physical stress where the muscle contraction occurs at or near the moment of death, such as in shootings, electrocution, or drowning.

choices.text: On the action line
Before the action line
On the alert line
After the alert line

questions.text: In a Partogram, where do you start plotting the cervical dilatation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) On the alert line

 

Explanation:

 

In the WHO modified partograph, labor progression is charted using alert and action lines. The cervical dilatation is plotted starting in the active phase of labor, typically at 4 cm dilation.

 

  • Alert Line: Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line.
  • Action Line: Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. On the action line: Plotting starts on the alert line, not the action line. The action line is used for intervention planning.

 

Option B. Before the action line: This is incorrect as the plotting starts on the alert line.

 

Option D. After the alert line: This is incorrect since plotting should start on the alert line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Partogram, cervical dilatation is first plotted on the alert line, which indicates the expected rate of progress in labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: A female with breast cancer undergoes investigation which reveals the presence of ER positivity. Presence of ER is important as it is a:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Predictive marker

 

Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity in breast cancer is primarily used as a predictive marker. The presence of ER indicates that the cancer cells are likely to respond to hormonal therapies such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. These therapies work by blocking estrogen receptors or decreasing estrogen levels in the body, which helps slow or stop the growth of ER-positive breast cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic marker: The presence of ER is not used to diagnose breast cancer, as normal breast tissue can also express estrogen receptors. Therefore, ER positivity alone cannot confirm a diagnosis of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Prognostic marker: While ER status can provide some prognostic information, such as indicating a potentially better outcome due to responsiveness to hormone therapy, it is not solely used for prognosis. Prognostic factors typically include tumor size, lymph node status, and other molecular markers.

 

Option D. Surrogate molecular marker: A surrogate molecular marker is used as a substitute for a clinical endpoint. ER positivity does not serve as a surrogate molecular marker in this context; instead, it directly informs the treatment approach and potential response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER positivity in breast cancer is a predictive marker that helps determine the likelihood of response to hormonal therapies, making it crucial for guiding treatment decisions.

 

Additional classification:

questions.text: Shape of Trapezius muscle is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Triangular

 

Explanation:

 

  • The trapezius muscle is a large, triangular and paired muscle located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax. 
  • Each trapezius muscle is flat and triangularly shaped, with the base of the triangle situated along the vertebral column (the muscle's origin) and the apex pointing toward the tip of the shoulder (the muscle's insertion).

 

 

  • Trapezius muscle shape:
    • Considering left or right side - triangular shape
    • Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trapezius muscle:

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, polyanionic

 

Based on the given graph, that A has the highest filterability, followed by B and C, it is likely that A has a smaller size and/or a positive charge, making it easier to pass through the filtration membrane. Similarly, C is likely larger and/or negatively charged, leading to reduced filterability. Therefore, the answer would be: Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

 

Negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for the differential filtration of charged substances. The order of filterability observed in the graph suggests that A is polycationic, B is neutral, and C is polyanionic. This is because polycationic substances would be readily filtered due to their positive charge, while polyanionic substances would be repelled by the negatively charged barrier and exhibit low filterability. Neutral substances would fall somewhere in between, depending on their size and shape. The molecular size exclusion limit you mentioned (between 4-8 nm) is also important for determining which substances are able to be filtered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filterability of substances through the kidney glomerular filtration barrier depends on their charge and size. Polycationic substances (positively charged) filter most readily, neutral substances have intermediate filterability, and polyanionic substances (negatively charged) have the least filterability due to repulsion by the negatively charged barrier.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is the xenodiagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xeno-diagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Diagnosis of Chagas disease. Laboratory bred Reduviid bugs (vector/ foreign host) are allowed to feed on the suspected patients (original host). After 4-5 weeks, the feces of the bugs are microscopically examined for amastigote forms of Trypanosoma cruzi (pathogen).
  2. Identification of dengue virus - Intrathoracic inoculation of the mosquitoes (vector) with viruses (pathogen). The virus multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, muscle biopsy bits from suspected patients are fed to laboratory rats (vector) for T. spiralis. The larvae of T. spiralis can be demonstrated in the muscles of the infected lab rats.

 

Advantage of xeno-diagnosis: It is useful in cases where a direct microscopic diagnosis is difficult due to the low count of pathogens in the blood of the host/patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC: This is not a xenodiagnostic method but a laboratory assay to test the enterotoxigenicity of ETEC (Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli).

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: This method is not classified as xenodiagnosis; it is a form of animal inoculation for diagnosing Leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: This is the Elek test for diphtheria toxin production and is not a xenodiagnostic method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to detect the presence of pathogens by allowing the vector to feed on or be injected with the patient's tissue, then examining the vector for the pathogen. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is a classic example of this diagnostic method.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C5

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.

 

The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.

 

Deltoid is supplied by axillary nerve which has the root value of C4-C6. The C5 component is responsible for abduction.Other components help in flexion and extensionm at shoulder joint

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.

 

Option C. C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.

 

Option D. C7: The C7 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow and wrist flexion and finger extension. It is not directly involved in shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the shoulder

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dL and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

 

IV fluids are the next best management as the patient is in shock and needs immediate correction. ABG here could show HAGMA secondary to type A lactic acidosis or ketoacidosis. Hence, ABG wouldn’t help in the diagnosis here. Shock in patient with DKA is not common and suggest an underlying sepsis as excess glucotoxicity causes shift of H2O to the intravascular compartment. IV fluid bolus is given in the emergency immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin therapy is critical in the management of DKA, it should only be started after initial fluid resuscitation has been commenced and any electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium, have been assessed and addressed.

 

Option C. Arterial blood gas: While ABG can provide valuable information about the severity of acidosis and help guide management, it is not the immediate next step before ensuring adequate fluid resuscitation.

 

Option D. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV: An insulin bolus can potentially exacerbate hypokalemia in the setting of DKA. Fluid resuscitation and stabilization should precede any insulin bolus or infusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of DKA presenting with signs of dehydration and shock, the initial management should focus on aggressive fluid resuscitation to stabilize the patient before initiating insulin therapy. This approach not only addresses the immediate life-threatening condition but also prepares the body for further metabolic correction.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/DKA/Chapter 404

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin

 

Explanation

 

All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

 

Gastric Acid Secretion:

 

  • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.

 

Stimulation of ECL Cells:

 

  1. Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  2. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  3. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.

 

Role of Serotonin:

 

  • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text: As a researcher designing a clinical study, you are exploring methods to eliminate confounding variables, which can lead to spurious associations between the independent and dependent variables. Which of the following methods is NOT primarily used to eliminate confounders? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Blinding

 

  • This method is used primarily to prevent bias in the conduct and interpretation of clinical research.
  • Blinding can be of participants, investigators, or those assessing outcomes, to ensure that the behaviors and evaluations are not influenced by knowledge of which treatment or intervention participants receive.
  • While blinding reduces bias, it does not specifically address the issue of confounding variables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Randomization: By randomly assigning participants to different groups in a study, randomization aims to evenly distribute confounding variables across all groups, thus reducing their potential impact on the outcome. This helps ensure that any differences observed between groups can more reliably be attributed to the intervention itself rather than to external variables.

 

Option C. Restriction: This involves limiting the participants in a study to certain criteria, effectively isolating specific characteristics and reducing variation that could lead to confounding. For example, a study may restrict participants to a certain age range, gender, or health status to control for these variables.

 

Option D. Matching: Matching involves pairing participants in the treatment group with similar participants in the control group based on certain characteristics (e.g., age, sex, baseline health status). This technique helps to ensure that the treatment and control groups are comparable on these characteristics, thereby controlling for confounding variables related to them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blinding is used to remove Bias.

 

Confounding can be removed by:

 

  1. Matching (MC used /simplest)
  2. Randomisation (2nd Best Method)
  3. Restriction
  4. Stratification
  5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  6. Stratified Randomization (Overall Best Method)

questions.text: The possible diagnosis for a child whose mother had a history of bronchial asthma & child developed itchy plaques bilaterally over the popliteal fossa, & cubital fossa (as shown below) could be? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays a child, with scratch marks and excoriations from itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, with a maternal history of bronchial asthma indicative of

 

Atopic dermatitis (or eczema).

 

  • This chronic inflammatory skin condition often occurs in families with atopy, encompassing asthma, hay fever, and allergic rhinitis.
  • The patient's personal history reveals a chronic and recurrent course of this condition.

 

In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.

 

  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  • Infantile
  • Childhood
  • Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas.
  • Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following 
    • Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any topic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • It is frequently observed in individuals in their 40s.
  • This is an intensely pruritic condition predominantly affecting extensor surfaces of the body, rather than the flexures and associated with gluten sensitivity and is characterized by grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. It is not related to a history of atopy.

 

Option C. Pemphigus vegetans:

 

  • A variant of pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus vegetans presents with vegetating plaques, usually in the intertriginous areas.
  • It is not associated with a familial history of atopy and does not predominantly affect the popliteal and cubital fossae.

 

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, scaly plaques.
  • While psoriasis can affect any area of the body but more commonly extensor involvement is seen, it does not typically present as pruritic plaques in the popliteal

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with a familial history of atopy presenting with itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, Atopic Dermatitis is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19, volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Image source:

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Atopic_dermatitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports to the police after being sexually assaulted by her employer. During the forensic examination, white stains were found on her clothing. To identify the nature of the stains, Barberio’s test was performed, revealing the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals. What substance is detected by Barberio’s test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Spermine

 

Explanation:

 

 

Barberio’s test is used to detect the presence of spermine, a component of semen secreted by the prostate gland. In this test, an alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the dried seminal stain, which reacts to form yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. The presence of these crystals confirms the detection of spermine, indicating that the stain likely contains semen. Barberio’s test is part of the microchemical tests used in the presumptive identification of seminal stains.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is an enzyme found in high concentrations in semen, primarily produced by the prostate gland. Although commonly used in seminal stain detection, it is not identified by Barberio’s test, but rather through an enzymatic colorimetric reaction.

 

B. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA): PSA is a protein produced by the prostate gland and is a marker used in the confirmatory tests for semen, especially when no sperm cells are present. However, Barberio’s test does not detect PSA.

 

D. Creatine phosphokinase: Creatine phosphokinase is found in spermatozoa and can be used in some confirmatory tests for semen detection. However, it is not the target substance in Barberio’s test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Barberio’s test is a microchemical test used for the presumptive detection of spermine, a prostatic component of semen, by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. This test is part of the forensic analysis of seminal stains, providing valuable evidence in sexual assault investigations.

questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO2 – 80 mm Hg? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO3- ions.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to a primary reduction in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not associated with elevated pCO2 levels, which are seen in respiratory acidosis.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary increase in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not consistent with the low pH and high pCO2 levels seen in the patient.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary decrease in pCO2 levels, often caused by hyperventilation. It is the opposite of the patient's condition, which shows low pH and high pCO2 levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a low blood pH and elevated pCO2 levels, suggesting impaired respiratory function and CO2 retention as the primary cause of the acidosis.

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-15

questions.text: SAFE strategy for trachoma includes all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evaluation of control program

 

In the SAFE strategy, ‘E’ stands for Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation.

 

Effective interventions for trachoma blindness have been demonstrated in developing nations using the SAFE strategy –

 

  • Surgery (S): Performed to correct trichiasis, which is the inward turning of the eyelashes that can lead to corneal damage and blindness. This intervention helps prevent further damage to the cornea.
  • Antibiotics (A): Used to treat the infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Mass drug administration is typically used in endemic areas to reduce the prevalence of the infection.
  • Facial cleanliness (F): Encouraged to reduce transmission of the bacterium among community members, especially children who are more susceptible to infection.
  • Environmental improvement (E): Focuses on improving living conditions, such as increasing access to clean water and better sanitation facilities, to reduce the spread of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following declarations with their primary focus or motive: (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 1-ii, 2-iii, 3-iv, 4-i

 

Explanation:

 

  • Declaration of Geneva (1948): This declaration is a modernized version of the Hippocratic Oath, outlining the ethical duties and responsibilities of physicians.
  • Declaration of Helsinki (1964): This declaration sets ethical guidelines for medical research involving human subjects, emphasizing the importance of informed consent and the protection of participants' well-being.
  • Declaration of Tokyo (1975): This declaration addresses the role of physicians in preventing and opposing torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment.
  • Declaration of Oslo (1970): This declaration pertains to therapeutic abortion, outlining principles and guidelines for the medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

The other options present incorrect pairings between the declarations and their primary motives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's essential to be familiar with these key declarations and their significance in medical ethics and human rights. These documents guide the conduct of physicians and researchers worldwide.

choices.text: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intravenous route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intravenous route

questions.text: A patient was given ampicillin 2 g intravenously. After that, the person developed rash on skin, hypotension and difficulty in breathing. The patient should be managed by? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route

 

Penicillin’s are prone to cause allergic reactions. Features like rash on skin, hypotension, and difficulty in breathing are suggestive of anaphylactic shock.

 

In case of anaphylactic shock the resuscitation council of UK has recommended the following measures:

 

  • Put the patient in reclining position, administer oxygen at high flow rate and perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation if required.
  • Inject adrenaline 0.5 mg (0.5 ml of 1 in 1000 for adult, 0.3 ml for child 6-12 years and 0.15 ml for child upto 6 years) i.m.; repeat every 5-10 min in case patient does not improve or improvement is transient. This is the only life saving measure. Adrenaline should not be injected i.v. (can itself be fatal) unless shock is immediately life threatening. If adrenaline is to be injected i. v., it should be diluted to 1:10,000 and infused slowly with constant monitoring.
  • Administer a H1 antihistaminic (pheniramine 20-40 mg or chlorpheniramine 10-20 mg) i.m./slow i.v. It may have adjuvant value.
  • Intravenous glucocorticoid (hydrocortisone sod. succinate 200 mg) should be added in severe/recurrent cases. It acts slowly but is especially valuable for prolonged reactions and in asthmatics. It may be followed by oral prednisolone for 3 days.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 97

choices.text: 2,3 and 4
1,2,3 and 4
4 only
1 and 2 only

questions.text:
Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids

2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell

3. Decreased acetyl Co in TCA cycle

4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyrate synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

 

2, 3 and 4 statements correctly explain the reason behind increased ketogenesis as seen in type1 DM.

 

In Type 1 DM insulin is deficient and GLUT4 (insulin-dependent uptake) mediated glucose uptake is not possible in the heart or skeletal muscles. So, fat is mobilized from adipose tissue for energy.

 

 

The following points explain the reasons behind increased ketogenesis:

 

Statement 2: Increased Mobilization of Fat from the Adipose Cell: In type 1 DM, insulin deficiency leads to increased lipolysis in adipose tissue, resulting in the release of free fatty acids into the bloodstream. These fatty acids are transported to the liver, where they undergo beta-oxidation.

Statement 3: Decreased Acetyl CoA in the TCA Cycle: Insulin deficiency also leads to reduced availability of oxaloacetate in the liver, which is diverted to gluconeogenesis. This decreases the entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, causing an accumulation of acetyl CoA.

Statement 4: Increased Beta-Hydroxybutyrate Synthase: The increased concentration of acetyl CoA leads to the synthesis of ketone bodies, including beta-hydroxybutyrate. The enzyme beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of acetoacetate to beta-hydroxybutyrate.

 

Other Statements:

  • Decreased Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acids (1): This is incorrect. In type 1 DM, beta-oxidation of fatty acids is actually increased due to the elevated levels of free fatty acids resulting from enhanced lipolysis.

 

Additional Context:

In the absence of insulin, glucose uptake by cells is impaired, leading to increased lipolysis and subsequent beta-oxidation of fatty acids. The resulting acetyl CoA cannot enter the TCA cycle efficiently due to low levels of oxaloacetate, leading to the production of ketone bodies (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone).

 

Educational Objective

 

Ketosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue, decreased entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, and increased production of ketone bodies, particularly beta-hydroxybutyrate.

choices.text: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.text: A sensitive diagnostic test for a certain disease returns a positive result for a patient. What statement accurately describes the significance of a positive result from the sensitive test? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common

 

  • If a sensitive test yields a positive result, it indicates the presence of the disease, especially when the disease is prevalent.
  • The sensitivity of a screening test refers to its capacity to accurately identify individuals with the disease.
  • In simpler terms, sensitivity measures the test's capability to correctly spot true positives (TP) among all cases of the disease (TP+FN). 

 

Sensitivity = TP / TP + FN X 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It confirms that the person does not have the disease: Incorrect. A sensitive test returning a positive result indicates the presence, not the absence, of the disease.

 

Option B. It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease: Incorrect. If the disease is rare, the positive predictive value (PPV) might be low, and the result may be less reliable.

 

Option D. It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent: Incorrect. While a positive result is more likely in a prevalent disease, it does not solely rely on sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive result from a highly sensitive test confirms the presence of the disease, particularly when the disease is common.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

choices.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test
It is an extrasynovial structure
It is the main restraint to internal rotation
It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the main restraint to internal rotation

 

LIGAMENT INJURIES OF THE KNEE JOINT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCL is the an extrasynovial structure originating from the anterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch.
  • It is the main restraint to the posterior translation of the knee i.e., the backward gliding of the tibia over the femur.
  • While evaluating the patient during physical examination, PCL is the main restraint in the posterior drawer test.

choices.text: Hypernatremia and hypokalemia
Hemodilution and hyperkalemia
Metabolic alkalosis and bradycardia
Pulmonary edema with hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is found unresponsive in a freshwater lake after being submerged for an unknown duration. He is immediately transported to the emergency department, where resuscitation efforts are initiated. On examination, the patient is in a drowsy state with a pulse rate of 140/min and a respiratory rate of 30/min. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals metabolic acidosis, based on these findings, what are the typical physiological changes associated with freshwater drowning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Hemodilution and hyperkalemia

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of freshwater drowning, several key physiological changes occur due to the rapid absorption of large volumes of hypotonic water. The excessive absorption of water leads to hemodilution, which results in a significant decrease in plasma sodium levels, causing hyponatremia. The electrolyte imbalance, particularly hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, can provoke cardiac arrhythmias. Hyperkalemia occurs due to the release of intracellular potassium from swollen red blood cells that rupture in the hypotonic environment. These electrolyte disturbances, specifically hemodilution, hyponatremia, arrhythmias, and hyperkalemia, are characteristic findings in freshwater drowning and contribute significantly to the clinical complications observed in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Hypernatremia and hypokalemia: This combination is not typical of freshwater drowning. Hypernatremia suggests saltwater drowning due to dehydration effects from hypertonic water, which contrasts with the hemodilution seen in freshwater incidents.

 

C. Metabolic alkalosis and bradycardia: Metabolic alkalosis and bradycardia do not fit the presentation of freshwater drowning, where acidosis and tachyarrhythmias are more common due to the severe electrolyte imbalances, particularly hyperkalemia.

 

D. Pulmonary edema with hypercalcemia: Pulmonary edema is a potential complication of drowning; however, hypercalcemia is not related to freshwater drowning, where disturbances primarily involve sodium and potassium levels rather than calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In freshwater drowning, excessive fluid absorption causes hemodilution, leading to hyponatremia, arrhythmias due to electrolyte abnormalities, and hyperkalemia from the release of potassium from damaged red blood cells. Recognizing these changes is essential in managing the clinical complications associated with freshwater drowning.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Palpitations
  2. Elevated BNP Troponins
  3. Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo
  4. ECG suggestive of myocarditis
  5. Low LVEF in echo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5


Subclinical myocarditis may not present with symptoms like palpitations, but can show:

 

2. Elevated BNP/Troponins: Indicating myocardial injury.

3. Regional wall motion abnormalities: Seen on echocardiography.

4. ECG changes: Suggestive of myocarditis, such as non-specific ST-T changes.

5. Low LVEF: Indicative of impaired left ventricular function.

 

Other Option:
 

1. Palpitations are not a feature of subclinical myocarditis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.

 

Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.

 

 

Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

questions.text: Which of the following routes of administration will not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral

 

Hepatic first-pass metabolism refers to the process where the concentration of a drug is greatly reduced before it reaches the systemic circulation. This occurs primarily when drugs are metabolized in the liver after being absorbed.

 

When a drug is taken orally, it is absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract and then passes through the liver before reaching systemic circulation. This route is subject to significant hepatic first-pass metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sublingual: This route involves placing a drug under the tongue, where it is absorbed directly into the bloodstream through the tissues beneath the tongue. It bypasses the liver initially, thus avoiding hepatic first-pass metabolism.

 

Option C. Intravenous (IV): Intravenous administration delivers a drug directly into the bloodstream, completely bypassing the liver initially. Therefore, it does not undergo first-pass metabolism.

 

Option D. Transdermal: Transdermal administration involves applying a drug through the skin (e.g., via a patch). The drug is absorbed directly into systemic circulation, bypassing the liver initially and thus avoiding first-pass metabolism.

 

Note: Please read the question carefully, which does not bypass means which undergoes first pass metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The route of administration that does not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism is Oral. This is because drugs taken orally are absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and then pass through the liver where they may be metabolically altered before reaching the systemic circulation.

choices.text: At least 80g dietary fibre
<5 g salt intake everyday
< 30% of the calories should come from fat

questions.text: A diabetic patient's fasting blood glucose level is found to be 160 mg/dL. What will you advise the patient regarding non-pharmacological management? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 30% of the calories should come from fat

 

When advising a diabetic patient on non-pharmacological management, it is essential to focus on dietary and lifestyle modifications that can help control blood glucose levels and reduce cardiovascular risk.

 

It is advisable for less than 30% of daily caloric intake to come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and avoiding trans fats altogether. This recommendation helps in managing cholesterol levels and reducing cardiovascular risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At least 80g dietary fibre: The recommended daily intake of dietary fiber is 25 to 40 grams, not 80 grams. High fiber intake helps in controlling blood sugar levels.

 

Option B. <5 g salt intake everyday: The recommendation for sodium intake is less than 2.3 grams per day, with overall salt intake being less than 5 grams per day.

    

Option D. Cholesterol < 100g: There is no guideline recommending cholesterol intake to be less than 100 grams. Current guidelines focus more on overall fat intake and the types of fats consumed rather than specific cholesterol limits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diabetic patients, it is recommended that less than 30% of daily calories come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and trans fats being avoided. This helps in managing blood sugar levels and reducing cardiovascular risks.

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activated B cells  

 

Isotype switching is seen in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching: Conversion of one antibody class (isotype) to another resulting from the genetic rearrangement of heavy-chain constant-region genes in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching is dependent on the presence of both antigens and cytokines secreted by T-cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helper T cells: While Helper T cells (especially Th2 cells) provide the necessary cytokines that drive isotype switching in B cells, they themselves do not undergo isotype switching.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic T cells: Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) are involved in killing infected or cancerous cells and do not produce antibodies or undergo isotype switching.

 

Option D. Naive B cells: Naive B cells, which have not yet encountered their specific antigen, initially produce IgM and IgD. They do not undergo isotype switching until after activation by an antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotype switching is a process that occurs in activated B cells, allowing them to produce different classes of antibodies to effectively combat various types of pathogens.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caspase – 1

 

Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.

 

Pyroptosis is a type of controlled cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis that is mediated by IL-1. It takes part in the removal of microbially and necrotically affected cells.

 

Caspase-1 and the inflammasome complex are both activated.

 

  • IL-1 production causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Caspase - 3, C. Caspase - 9 and  D. Caspase – 8: These caspases are primarily involved in the apoptosis pathway, not in the activation of IL-1. Caspase-3 and caspase-9 are part of the apoptotic cascade that leads to programmed cell death without inflammation. Caspase-8 is involved in extrinsic apoptosis signaling and can overlap with inflammatory pathways but does not directly activate IL-1.

 

Educational objective:

 

Caspase-1 is critical for the activation of IL-1, directly linking it to the inflammatory response and distinguishing it from other caspases primarily involved in apoptotic pathways. This mechanism underscores the specific role of the inflammasome and pyroptosis in immune defense and inflammatory regulation.

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium.
  • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy.
  • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women with bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasonography should prompt further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 357

choices.text: Elemental calcium of 1200mg/ day is recommended
Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium
Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered
Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

questions.text: A 60-year post-menopausal obese lady presents with backache. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 1 year back. A DEXA scan shows a T score of less than - 2.5. Which of the following is false? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

 

Explanation:

 

Management of Osteoporosis:

 

  • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D:
    • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • Bisphosphonates:
    • Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density.
    • The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.
  • Teriparatide:
    • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates.
    • When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended: This statement is true. Adequate calcium intake is essential for bone health, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium: This statement is true. Vitamin D3 helps in the absorption of calcium and is recommended to be given along with calcium supplements.

 

Option C. Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered: This statement is true. Starting with teriparatide helps build bone density, and following with bisphosphonates helps maintain the gains.

 

Option D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year: This statement is false. Bisphosphonates can be given for a longer duration, typically 3-5 years, depending on the patient's individual risk factors and response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are typically recommended for a duration of 3-5 years in the treatment of osteoporosis, not limited to just 1 year.

 

Ref: Page no 500, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. Identify the true statement about intermittent claudication: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

 

Most commonly felt in the calf muscles: Correct. Intermittent claudication most commonly affects the calf muscles because the disease often affects the arteries supplying the lower limbs, usually the superficial femoral artery (70% of cases). Patients describe it as a cramping or aching sensation that occurs with walking or exertion and is relieved with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Felt at rest: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest. It occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles during exertion.

 

Option C. Day to day distance is variable: Incorrect. While the severity of peripheral artery disease can change over time (especially without treatment), typically, the distance a person can walk before symptoms begin is fairly consistent, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Relieved after getting out of bed: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication pain is typically relieved after a few minutes of rest and doesn't specifically correlate with getting out of bed. The pain usually occurs during physical activities, such as walking, and subsides with rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles due to the high prevalence of peripheral artery disease affecting the arteries that supply the lower limbs. This condition is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest.

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla – males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components – fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

choices.text: Rupture of valve
Calcification and fibrosis
Hypertrophy of ventricular wall
Hypertrophy of the atrial wall

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

 

The illustration depicts rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance. Calcification and fibrosis are the causes.

 

RHD is primarily identified by mitral stenosis, for which it is essentially the primary cause, and deforming fibrotic valvular disease.

 

The leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusing of the tendinous cords are the three primary anatomic alterations of the mitral valve in chronic RHD.

 

"Fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis are caused by calcification and fibrous bridging over the valvular commissures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of valve: Not indicated in the image or history provided.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of ventricular wall: While ventricular wall hypertrophy may occur due to increased workload from valvular heart disease, it is not visible on this image of the valve.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of the atrial wall: Similar to ventricular hypertrophy, atrial wall hypertrophy may occur in response to increased pressure from stenosed valves but is not the direct cause visible in the valve image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease, the mitral valve often undergoes significant morphological changes due to fibrosis and calcification, leading to stenosis with a characteristic "fish mouth" appearance. Understanding these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the progression of the disease.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady came to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a past history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug is maximum teratogenic to the fetus?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Valproate

 

  • Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the drugs used in bipolar disorder and anti-epileptic medications. It causes congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bifida), cleft lip and cleft palate, and cardiac anomalies. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children.
  • Although lithium is also teratogenic and can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, but it is less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: This medication is also used to treat bipolar disorder and epilepsy, but it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to valproate. The risk of major congenital malformations with lamotrigine is relatively low.

 

Option C. Oxcarbazepine: Used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, oxcarbazepine has a moderate risk of teratogenic effects, but it is still considered less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Option D. Olanzapine: This antipsychotic medication is used for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. While there are some risks associated with its use during pregnancy, including potential metabolic complications, it is not considered as teratogenic as valproate.

 

Additional Note on Lithium

 

Although lithium is also used to treat bipolar disorder and is known to be teratogenic, causing conditions like Ebstein's anomaly (a heart defect), its teratogenic risk is considered lower than that of valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the options listed, causing significant congenital anomalies such as neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, and cardiac anomalies, as well as poor cognitive development. It should be avoided in women who are planning to conceive or are pregnant.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe joint pain, predominantly affecting his knees. He has a history of chronic alcohol use, particularly home-distilled moonshine, and works in a battery manufacturing plant. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum uric acid levels and renal function tests showing reduced glomerular filtration rate. The joint fluid analysis is consistent with gout. Based on his occupational and environmental exposure history, what is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Lead intoxication

 

Explanation:

 

Saturnine gout is a type of gout caused by chronic lead intoxication, often associated with occupational exposure or ingestion of lead-contaminated substances, such as moonshine. Lead exposure results in tubulointerstitial renal damage, which impairs the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia and subsequent gout. Saturnine gout has a predilection for affecting the knee joints more frequently than the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe), which is typical in primary gout. The disproportionate elevation of uric acid relative to the reduction in glomerular filtration rate is characteristic of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Copper toxicity: Copper toxicity is mainly associated with Wilson’s disease, which causes hepatic, neurological, and psychiatric symptoms. It does not impair renal uric acid excretion and is not associated with gout.

 

B. Arsenic exposure: Arsenic poisoning is associated with multisystem effects, including gastrointestinal distress, neuropathy, and skin changes, but it is not known to cause gout or hyperuricemia. Unlike lead, arsenic does not specifically impair renal uric acid excretion.

 

D. Thallium poisoning: Thallium toxicity primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms, alopecia, and neurological effects, including peripheral neuropathy, but does not typically present with gout or hyperuricemia as seen in chronic lead intoxication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saturnine gout is a specific type of gout caused by chronic lead poisoning, which impairs renal excretion of uric acid and leads to hyperuricemia. It is often associated with occupational or environmental lead exposure, such as through battery manufacturing or consumption of lead-contaminated moonshine, and presents with gout symptoms that may predominantly affect the knees. Understanding the link between lead exposure and gout is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management in patients with relevant exposure history.

choices.text: Inhibition of 5-alpha reductase
Release of nitrous oxide radicals
Blockage of voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of sildenafil? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5
 

Sildenafil works by inhibiting PDE5, an enzyme that breaks down cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). Inhibition of PDE5 leads to increased levels of cGMP within the smooth muscle cells of the blood vessels, resulting in vasodilation, particularly in the corpus cavernosum of the penis, and thus facilitating erection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of 5-alpha reductase: This is not the mechanism of action of sildenafil. 5-alpha reductase inhibitors are typically used in the treatment of conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia and male pattern baldness.

 

Option C. Release of nitrous oxide radicals: Sildenafil does not release nitrous oxide; instead, its mechanism of action is closely linked to the nitric oxide (NO) pathway. NO is released during sexual stimulation and activates guanylate cyclase, which increases levels of cGMP. Sildenafil enhances the effects of NO by inhibiting PDE5, which degrades cGMP.

 

Option D. Blockage of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is not the mechanism of action of sildenafil. Calcium channel blockers are a class of medications that are used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions by preventing calcium ions from entering cells of the heart and blood vessel walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sildenafil works by inhibiting PDE-5, leading to increased levels of cGMP, which facilitates the relaxation of smooth muscle and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum. This mechanism makes option B the correct choice.

choices.text: Intermediate filaments

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

 

The clinical scenario given here describes alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments.

 

i) Hepatocellular necrosis:

 

ii) Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline:

 

These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in swollen and ballooned hepatocytes. They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin). They are best seen with connective tissue stains such as Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, as well as immunoperoxidase methods.

 

Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis, as they can be found in a variety of other conditions, including primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

iii) Inflammatory response: primarily polymorphs with some scattered mononuclear cells.

 

iv) Fibrosis: Pericellular and perivenular fibrosis that appears web-like or chickenwire-like. This is also termed as creeping collagenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a type of microfilament found in the cytoskeleton of cells, but it is not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option C. Microtubules: Microtubules are another component of the cytoskeleton, but they are not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option  D. Fibronectin: Fibronectin is a high-molecular-weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins such as integrins. It is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic alcoholic patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Mallory-Denk bodies are a characteristic histopathological finding. These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions consist of aggregated cytoskeletal intermediate filaments, specifically prekeratin.

questions.text:
Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Oxygen: simple diffusion
  2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion
  3. Sodium: voltage-gated channel
  4. Sodium: Secondary active transport
  5. Calcium: Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

1. Oxygen: Simple diffusion - It moves from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration across the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. No transport protein is required.

 

2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion - It moves from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration with the help of glucose transporters. No energy is required.

 

3. Sodium: Voltage-gated channel - It moves down the electrochemical gradient through the voltage-gated channels. These channels are opened by a change in the membrane potential.

 

4. Sodium: Secondary active transport - It moves against the electrochemical gradient with the help of a co-transporter protein. The energy is provided by the electrochemical gradient of another molecule such as sodium or hydrogen ions.

 

5. Calcium: Active transport - It moves against the concentration gradient with the help of ATP-powered pumps. These pumps maintain a low intracellular calcium concentration compared to the extracellular environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen moves by simple diffusion without a transport protein. Glucose uses facilitated diffusion with transporters. Sodium uses both voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport. Calcium uses active transport via ATP-powered pumps.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mannitol

 

The patient is experiencing Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), a complication that can occur during or after hemodialysis, especially in patients with initially very high urea levels undergoing dialysis for the first time. DDS is caused by a rapid decrease in urea levels in the blood, leading to a sudden change in osmolarity, which causes water to move into the cells, resulting in cerebral edema and neurological symptoms such as drowsiness and seizures.

 

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS): This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms due to cerebral edema caused by rapid changes in blood urea levels during dialysis.
  • Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic is used to treat cerebral edema by reducing intracranial pressure and drawing fluid out of the brain cells, thus decreasing cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bumetanide: This loop diuretic is used for fluid overload but not specifically indicated for treating cerebral edema in DDS.

 

Option B. Ethacrynic acid: Another loop diuretic, similar to bumetanide, and not used for DDS.

 

Option C. Nesiritide: A recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide used in acute heart failure, not for treating DDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment for Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), which can occur during or after dialysis, involves reducing cerebral edema. The first-line treatment is mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

 

Explanation:

 

The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:

 

  • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy: COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.

 

However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.

 

Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 489
